title: Analyzing Sabalenka's Psychological Resilience and Dominance in Professional Tennis
summary: The article examines Aryna Sabalenka's recent Australian Open match against Anastasia Potapova, where the world number one faced significant emotional challenges despite being a heavy favorite. Sabalenka described feeling 'emotionally all over the place' and 'disconnected from my body' as Potapova mounted a comeback, forcing Sabalenka to save four set points before securing a 7-6 (7-4) 7-6 (9-7) victory. This match serves as a case study in Sabalenka's psychological development, as she reflected that earlier in her career, such emotional turmoil would have led to defeat. Sabalenka has actively worked with a psychologist to enhance her mental fortitude, shifting her focus from emotional states to mentality and resilience. Her career trajectory includes winning the Australian Open in 2023 and 2024, reaching at least the semi-finals in 13 of the past 16 Grand Slam tournaments, and accumulating four major titles over three seasons, establishing her as a dominant force in women's tennis. The article underscores the interplay between emotional management and athletic performance, highlighting Sabalenka's evolution into a mentally tougher competitor.

In elite sports, psychological factors like resilience and emotional control are critical for success, often addressed through interventions like working with psychologists.
